div.p: Colonial Secretary's Office, acc. 36, vol. 493, f. 37, Western Australian State Archives, J. S. Battye Library of West Australian History, Perth.

From the position I have the honor to hold as the head of this great Botanical Establishment, it becomes my duty to lend every aid in my power to further a knowledge of plants, especially of the useful plants, particularly in our Colonies . His Grace the Duke of Newcastle has taken a deep interest in this subject & required me to give him a proximate estimat of the cost of preparing Floras of the respective British Colonies: & one of the first he was desirous to have published on account of its extent & the very novel character of its vegetation, was that of all Australia.

The enclosed printed paper
A copy of G. Bentham to [W.] Hooker, 6 May 1861 printed for private circulation. will explain fully what I wish to state to you. I was authorized to put myself in communication with the respective Colonies & enquire how far they were disposed to unite & contriubte the needful expenses. Among the rest of course Western Australia was included. I have received (& the Duke of Newcastle too has received) the most favorable responses, from every Governor save Western Australia.

On my mentioning this circumstance at the Colonial Office, I was told that new Governor was poointed: my letters having been addressed to your predecessor. I now therefore take the great liberty of addressing you; & should you be favorable to the plan, you will perhaps think it right to recommend it to the legislature; in that case you will perhaps dome the honour to write to me.
Indeed, I think, very probably the other Governors may already have been in communication with you on the subject.
